text: What is the autonomy level of the AI agent?

options.label: Narrow
options.description: Single-tool, single-step actions (e.g., auto-reply to email, simple API call)

options.label: Bounded
options.description: Multi-step actions with guardrails (e.g., customer service bot that can issue refunds within limits)

options.label: Broad
options.description: Open-ended planning and execution (e.g., coding agent, research agent, autonomous decision-maker)

regulatoryRelevance: Autonomy level directly affects risk classification under Singapore's IMDA Agentic AI Framework (risk bounding dimension) and EU AI Act human oversight requirements (Article 14). Higher autonomy demands stricter controls.

text: What tools, APIs, or systems can the AI agent access? List all (e.g., email, payment APIs, databases, web browser, code execution).
regulatoryRelevance: Tool access scope determines the blast radius of agent actions. Singapore IMDA framework requires limiting tool access as a risk bounding control. Broader tool access increases risk classification.

text: What real-world actions can the agent take? Select all that apply.

options.label: Send communications
options.description: Send emails, messages, notifications on behalf of users

options.label: Make payments/transactions
options.description: Initiate financial transactions, payments, or transfers

options.label: Modify data
options.description: Create, update, or delete records in databases or systems

options.label: Execute code
options.description: Run code, scripts, or commands on systems

options.label: Browse the web
options.description: Access and interact with websites and web services

options.label: Access/modify files
options.description: Read, create, edit, or delete files on systems

options.label: Manage accounts
options.description: Create, modify, or close user accounts or subscriptions

options.label: Other actions
options.description: Other real-world actions not listed above

regulatoryRelevance: Action scope determines potential harm magnitude. Financial transactions trigger financial services regulations. Data modification triggers data protection requirements. Singapore IMDA framework requires explicitly bounding action scope.

text: Are there defined points where human approval is required before the agent can proceed?
regulatoryRelevance: Human checkpoints are a core requirement of Singapore's IMDA Agentic AI Framework (human accountability dimension) and EU AI Act Article 14 human oversight requirements. Absence of checkpoints increases risk tier.

text: Do multiple AI agents interact or collaborate in your system?
regulatoryRelevance: Multi-agent systems create complex accountability chains. Singapore IMDA framework specifically addresses multi-agent accountability. EU AI Act requires clear responsibility allocation across interacting AI systems.

text: Can the agent access external systems or third-party APIs beyond your organization's infrastructure?
regulatoryRelevance: External system access expands the risk boundary and may trigger cross-border data transfer requirements. Singapore IMDA framework requires bounding external access as a risk control.

text: Does the system have failsafe mechanisms such as kill switches, automatic rollback, iteration limits, or budget caps?
regulatoryRelevance: Failsafe mechanisms are a technical control requirement under Singapore's IMDA Agentic AI Framework. EU AI Act requires stop mechanisms for high-risk systems. Absence of failsafes is a significant compliance gap.

text: Are all agent actions logged with timestamps and sufficient detail for audit and review?
regulatoryRelevance: Action logging is required for auditability under Singapore IMDA framework (technical controls dimension), EU AI Act automatic logging requirements (Article 12), and general compliance best practices.
